solution_line_template: Each kettle has {pregnancies_per_kettle} hawks that get pregnant and each one yields {babies_per_pregnancy} babies per pregnancy so there are {pregnancies_per_kettle} * {babies_per_pregnancy}= <<{pregnancies_per_kettle}*{babies_per_pregnancy}={babies_per_kettle}>>{babies_per_kettle} babies expected per kettle.

If {babies_per_kettle} baby hawks are expected per kettle and the ornithologists are tracking {num_kettles} kettles total then there are {babies_per_kettle} * {num_kettles}=<<{babies_per_kettle}*{num_kettles}={total_expected_babies}>>{total_expected_babies} baby hawks expected across all six kettles this breeding season.

If there {loss_percentage_num}% of eggs do not hatch, then we are looking for {loss_percentage_num} (percent that do not make it) /{percent_divisor} (total number of babies expected)=<<{loss_percentage_num}/{percent_divisor}={loss_proportion}>>{loss_proportion} (percentage converted to decimal form for the proportion of expected baby hawks to be lost).

The total number of baby hawks expected equals {total_expected_babies} * {loss_proportion} expected los s= <<{total_expected_babies}*{loss_proportion}={babies_lost}>>{babies_lost} babies not expected to hatch (lost).

There are {total_expected_babies} total number of baby hawks expected and there are {babies_lost} babies expected to be lost so {total_expected_babies}-{babies_lost}= <<{total_expected_babies}-{babies_lost}={remaining_babies}>>{remaining_babies} remaining baby hawks expected this breeding season
